chapter: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: Which view will best assess the maxillary sinus for potential fractures?
questions.explanation: often involved in facial trauma like Le Fort fractures. PNS and Orbit X-Ray views: Views Position X-ray & structure/disease used Waters’ View (Option A) Maxillary sinus Partially frontal sinus Caldwell’s View (Option B) Frontal sinus (mainly) Ethmoid sinus Lateral View (Option C) All sinuses visible Mastoid antrum/air cells Submentovertex View (Option D) Sphenoid sinus (from the base of skull) Towne’s View (AP Axial) Occipital bone fractures Posterior cranial fossa pathologies
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: Which of the following sinuses does NOT drain through the osteomeatal unit?
questions.explanation: Osteomeatal Unit (OMU): Key structure in the middle meatus of the nasal cavity, serving as the drainage pathway for the frontal, anterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses. It is a crucial region because blockages here often lead to chronic or recurrent sinusitis. Components of the Osteomeatal Unit: Uncinate Process: A thin, curved bone that is part of the lateral nasal wall which serves as a boundary for the drainage pathways of the sinuses. Semilunar Hiatus: A crescent-shaped groove located beneath the middle nasal turbinate.It is the primary drainage pathway for the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses. Ethmoidal Bulla: A prominent ethmoid air cell located just above the semilunar hiatus.It is the largest of the anterior ethmoid air cells and plays a role in sinus drainage. Infundibulum : A funnel-shaped passage that connects the maxillary sinus to the semilunar hiatus. Reference: Ct pns anatomy OMU
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: Following CT image is kept as a spotter in your final year exam viva. What is the marked structure?
questions.explanation: Haller cell - an example of anterior ethmoidal air cell . Ethmoidal air cells: Anterior Air cells: Agger Nasi Anterior most air cell of Ethmoid sinus Site: Within the Lacrimal bone in the medial side of the Orbit Relation: Anterolateral and inferior to the frontal recess Haller cell Infraorbital ethmoid air cell Site: Present between floor of orbit and upper boundary of maxillary sinus Bulla ethmoidalis Most consistent and largest ethmoid air cell Located just posterior to the Agger nasi Posterior Air cells: Onodi cell Also known as spheno-ethmoidal air cell Close proximity to Optic nerve and Internal carotid artery Better appreciable on CT- axial view Concha bullosa (Option A): Pneumatization of middle turbinate Most common deformity seen in nose, non-pathological CT: Pneumatized superior turbinate (Option C): Occasionally the superior turbinate can undergo pneumatization CT:
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents with persistent nasal congestion, facial pain exacerbated by bending forward, thick yellow nasal discharge, and reduced olfaction for two weeks. CT imaging reveals abnormalities in the paranasal sinuses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: discharge, and the findings on CT imaging showing sinus mucosal thickening and frothy fluid appearnace indicate maxillary sinusitis. Sinusitis: Inflammation of the mucosal lining of the paranasal sinuses, often associated with infection/allergy. Types: Acute Sinusitis: Duration Symptoms lasting less than 4 weeks Radiology CT: Frothy appearance due to presence of bubbles in fluid Treatment Most cases resolve spontaneously; symptomatic relief with nasal decongestants, saline nasal sprays, and analgesics. Antibiotics if bacterial infection is suspected (typically after 7-10 days of symptoms). Subacute sinusitis: Symptoms lasting 4 to 12 weeks. Chronic sinusitis: Duration Symptoms lasting longer than 12 weeks. Radiology CT: Bony sclerosis is seen and no air. Treatment Intranasal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation. Saline irrigation. Antibiotics for bacterial exacerbations. Surgery (e.g., functional endoscopic sinus surgery) in refractory cases to improve drainage. Complications of sinusitis: Orbital cellulitis or abscess Osteomyelitis of the skull Meningitis Intracranial abscess Viral rhinitis ( Option A): presents with clear nasal discharge and lacks significant mucosal thickening or air-fluid levels on imaging. Allergic rhinitis (Option B): Allergic rhinitis is characterized by clear rhinorrhea, nasal itching, and sneezing, without purulent discharge or air-fluid levels. Nasal polyps (Option D): Nasal polyps may cause nasal obstruction but are not typically associated with acute purulent discharge or air-fluid levels on imaging.
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: The imaging below shows a double density sign in the paranasal sinuses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: sinusitis, indicating the presence of centrally hyperdense fungal material within the sinuses. Allergic fungal sinusitis: Etiopathogenesis Allergic reaction to fungal organism (usually Aspergillus) Clinical presentation Age: 20-40 year females B/L nasal polyposis : causing nasal obstruction Characteristic peanut butter discharge: due to thick eosinophilic mucus Bent & Kuhn criteria (used for Diagnosis) Major criteria Minor criteria Type-I Hypersensitivity Nasal polyposis Characteristic CT findings Eosinophilic mucin Positive fungal stain Asthma Unilateral disease Bone erosion ( X-ray ) Serum eosinophilia Positive fungal culture Charcot-leyden crystals Radiology CT: Double density sign
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: A 20-year old male, following a fist fight where he got hit over his front face presented with pain and swelling over his nose. A leak from the nasal cavity was noted, watery in consistency. What is the initial investigation of choice to localize the site of leak?
questions.explanation: consistency). Beta-2-transferrin assay (Option B): IOC for CSF Rhinorrhea HRCT (Option C): Radiological IOC for localization of leak CT Cisternography (can be combined with MR Cisternography) can be done when HRCT is inconclusive. CSF Rhinorrhea: Filter paper test: Double halo sign/ Target sign Beta-2-transferrin assay: Confirms presence of CSF Glucose estimation: around 60 mg/dL - suggests presence of CSF Other laboratory tests: Beta-trace proteins, Intrathecal fluorescein test HRCT: CT Cisternography: Nasal Bone fracture: X-ray lateral view: X-ray PNS (Option A): Though done commonly, is not an useful investigation for localizing the site of leak. CT Angiography (Option D): Arteries are nowhere related to CSF Rhinorrhea and hence not used. Learning objective: Kero’s classification: Radiological classification used to determine the height of Olfactory fossa based on the height of lateral lamella of cribriform plate (evaluated in CT). Three categories: Type-I 1-3 mm depth Type-II 4-7 mm depth (most common type) Type-III ≥ 8 mm depth ( ↑ risk of CSF rhinorrhea)
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: Daniel, a 60 year old male presented with complaints of nasal obstruction and epistaxis. MRI Head showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: arising from lateral wall of nose is suggestive of Inverted papilloma. Inverted papilloma: (aka) [Transitional cell papilloma (or) Ringertz tumor] Description Tumor of non-olfactory mucosa of nose and paranasal sinus. Radiology Radiological IOC: MRI > CT - shows cerebriform appearance (Option B) Other options: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option A) IOC: Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT) shows Holman miller sign (also known as) Antral sign - anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus. Esthesio- neuroblastoma (Option C) IOC: MRI >> CT, ‘Figure of 8’ appearance with waist over cribriform plate is seen in MRI. Antrochoanal polyp (Option D) IOC: CECT - shows mass arising from maxillary sinus extending into the nasal cavity with widening of osteomeatal complex.
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: A 30-year-old female presents with right ear bleeding and conductive hearing loss (Rinne negative, Weber lateralized to right following head trauma.CT findings as shown as below.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: ear bleeding and conductive hearing loss with CT image showing a fracture line along the long axis of the temporal bone is suggestive of Longitudinal fracture of Right temporal bone. Temporal Bone fracture types: Longitudinal fracture Transverse fracture Description Fracture line across the/parallel to the long axis of the

questions.question: A 20-weeks primigravida complaints of severe headache, nausea and vomiting. MRI done showed the following. Which of the following combinations of diagnosis and investigation of choice is most appropriate?

options.A: Tortuous internal carotid artery; CT angiogram

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Sigmoid sinus thrombosis; MR venogram Explanation: A pregnant female with severe headache associated with nausea/vomiting with thrombosis present over sigmoid sinus and absent flow void (as seen in MRI) is diagnostic of Sigmoid Sinus thrombosis .MR venogram is the investigation of choice for diagnosing sigmoid sinus thrombosis, as it provides detailed visualization of venous structures and can accurately

questions.question: Following sign was seen while performing a radiological investigation Identify the investigation and the corresponding diagnosis.

options.C: Digital subtraction Angiography- Carotid body tumor

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Digital subtraction Angiography- Carotid body tumor Explanation: Investigation shown is Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) and Lyre sign is seen at the carotid bifurcation, which is suggestive of Carotid body tumor - a type of Paraganglioma. Radiological findings in carotid body tumor: NCCT Large well defined mass seen over carotid bifurcation CECT Well defined peripherally enhancing lesion at carotid bifurcation MRI (T2-weighted) Mass splaying the carotid bifurcation is seen MR Angiogram Bilateral carotid body tumor seen Digital subtraction Angiography (DSA) Lyre sign positive (Option C)

questions.question: An elderly male presented with unilateral hearing loss associated with tinnitus came. Investigation done showed the following appearance. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation: Vestibular schwannoma: Radiology Investigation of choice/Gold standard: MRI with Gadolinium contrast - ice cream cone appearance seen on CP angle . Other investigations: CT (with/without contrast): done when MRI is not feasible Vertebral Angiography: though helps in localizing the tumor, it is not the investigation of choice.
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: Young female with lower jaw swelling, X-ray showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.explanation: known as ameloblastoma. X-ray: soap bubble lesion (no matrix calcification) Differential diagnoses for jaw lesions: 1) Pindborg tumor: Calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumor . More common in the premolar and molar region of the lower jaw. Radiology: X-ray: shows snow driven appearance. CT: Radiolucent with scattered areas of calcification. Confirmation of diagnosis is done by Biopsy (gold standard) . 2) Sialolithiasis: Calculi of the salivary gland ducts - submandibular gland is involved most commonly. Radiology: >80% of the stones are radiopaque , hence X-ray/CT is preferred over USG. Sialography: useful in localizing the stone in the duct. 3) Ranula: Mucous extravasation cyst secondary to obstruction of minor salivary glands . Origin: Sublingual space - floor of mouth. Can complicate into Plunging ranula (retention cyst) . Radiology: CT.
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: Match the following X-rays with the corresponding pathologies 1) a) Coin in trachea 2) b) Coin in esophagus c) Button battery in esophagus d) Button battery in trachea
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: The MRI images below display a "tram-track" sign, characterized by enhancement surrounding the optic nerve. This radiological feature is most indicative of which condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) ) Optic nerve sheath meningioma Explanation: Image is that of a FLAIR-MRI showing tram-track sign due to thickening of meninges, suggestive of Optic sheath meningioma (not Glioma) (Option C) Optic sheath meningioma & Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve glioma Optic sheath meningioma Fusiform swelling of the optic nerve (option B ruled out) Tram-track sign (thickening of meninges) Associated with NF-1 Associated with NF-2 Optic neuritis (Option A): typically presents with diffuse enlargement and enhancement of the optic nerve itself due to inflammation. Orbital pseudotumor (Option B) can involve various orbital structures and often presents with a more diffuse, infiltrative mass without the distinct "tram-track" enhancement pattern.
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology

questions.question: A 30-year old female visited an Ophthalmology clinic with complaints of proptosis, difficulty in eye mobility and redness of eyes. Her TFT values were T3/T4-high, TSH-low. Which of the following structures shown in the right orbit is first to be affected first in her condition?
questions.explanation: Inferior rectus (3) > Medial rectus (2 ) > Superior rectus (1) > Lateral rectus (4). CT image shows Right orbit with Extraocular muscles - enlarged Inferior and medial rectus is seen. MRI: T1WI shows Coke bottle sign in the axial view Differential diagnoses: Thyroid eye disease Pseudotumor of orbit Tolosa hunt syndrome Tendon is spared
questions.chapter_heading: Head Neck Imaging-Head And Neck Radiology
